dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Critical and skeptical discussion about a business topic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we're talking about Nikola today, right? I mean, wow, this company had a real splashy entry onto the market, uh, after that reverse merger with VectoIQ. Remember that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we're talking about Nikola today, right? I mean, wow, this company had a real splashy entry onto the market, uh, after that reverse merger with Vecto I Q. Remember that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With plans to shake up commercial trucking with zero-emission vehicles and fuel, its the most audacious Wall Street debut for a high-tech transportation startup since Teslas a decade ago. ... The reverse merger with publicly traded VectoIQ, an acquisition firm created by former General Motors GM Vice Chairman Steve Girsky, was announced March 3, just ahead of the Covid-19 shutdown.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. NKLA, right? Like, started trading Thursday, ringing the bell on Nasdaq, or whatever Milton said. Trevor Milton, the founder, was all, "We're full steam ahead! Kicking ass!" Big talk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. N K L A, right? Like, started trading Thursday, ringing the bell on Nasdaq, or whatever Milton said. Trevor Milton, the founder, was all, We're full steam ahead! Kicking ass! Big talk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of the combined new company start trading Thursday with the ticker NKLA. ... We're full steam ahead, says Nikola founder Trevor Milton... NKLA on Thursday raining of the bell on Nasdaq. Approved! Trevor Milton (@nikolatrevor) June 2, 2020 ... We're kicking ass.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then you dig a little deeper, and it's, um, it's a bit of a mess, financially. They've lost, like, $600 million just trying to get these hydrogen semis into production.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then you dig a little deeper, and it's, um, it's a bit of a mess, financially. They've lost, like, six hundred million dollars just trying to get these hydrogen semis into production.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nikola has raised about $600 million to get its hydrogen semis into production at a new plant in Coolidge, Arizona, gaining a $3 billion valuation prior to the VectoIQ merger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And they're eyeing another $700 million in equity financing, plus debt, by 2024. I mean, the Coolidge, Arizona plant, with a $3 billion valuation, is just, like, *facing* issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And they're eyeing another seven hundred million dollars in equity financing, plus debt, by twenty twenty four. I mean, the Coolidge, Arizona plant, with a three billion dollar valuation, is just, like, facing issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company estimates it will need to raise an additional $700 million of equity financing between late 2021 and early 2022, according to an SEC filing. Additionally, it will probably issue debt in 2023 and 2024 totaling $500 million. ... Nikola has raised about $600 million to get its hydrogen semis into production at a new plant in Coolidge, Arizona, gaining a $3 billion valuation prior to the VectoIQ merger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And don't forget, they were doing solar panels before this, right? And now they're talking about closing their U.S. gas model factory and building electric trucks out of Germany and Utah.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And don't forget, they were doing solar panels before this, right? And now they're talking about closing their U S gas model factory and building electric trucks out of Germany and Utah.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Along with Iveco, Nikola also counts Bosch, Meritor, South Korean solar panel maker Hanwha and Norways Nel as key industrial partners... We have trucks coming out of Ulm, Germany, in full production next year, and then the year after here in Arizona, and we're about ready to break ground here.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just a lot of moving parts. And the hydrogen tech itself, I mean, it's been around since the sixties, but the article says the costs are rising and the technology's actually *declining* in viability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just a lot of moving parts. And the hydrogen tech itself, I mean, it's been around since the sixties, but the article says the costs are rising and the technology's actually declining in viability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fuel cell technology... has been around since the 1960s, but earlier iterations were far too costly and not durable enough for heavy daily use. Thats changed dramatically in the past decade, with costs for the materials and fuel tanks dropping steadily as the technology matured.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Yeah, and, uh, the "dirty hydrogen" from water and fossil fuels? Not exactly endearing them to environmental regulators, especially in places like California.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and, uh, the dirty hydrogen from water and fossil fuels? Not exactly endearing them to environmental regulators, especially in places like California.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While industrial hydrogen is typically sourced from natural gas, new methods for generating green hydrogen from water and electricity from solar or wind farms have made the fuel much more compelling to environmental regulators in California, Europe, Japan, South Korea and China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And Milton himself, he, uh, said something wild like, "We've shown how to destroy the entire industry," referring to how they made gasoline the "hottest topic." Like, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And Milton himself, he, uh, said something wild like, We've shown how to destroy the entire industry, referring to how they made gasoline the hottest topic. Like, what?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What I love about Nikola is we've shown how to disrupt the entire industry. At every (truck) group in the world now hydrogen is the hottest topic. And guess who did that? says Milton

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wild, indeed. But hey, they *do* have some big orders, like $10 billion worth, from companies led by Anheuser-Busch. That's a lot of trucks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild, indeed. But hey, they do have some big orders, like ten billion dollars worth, from companies led by Anheuser-Busch. That's a lot of trucks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nikola has secured truck orders worth $10 billion from companies led by Anheuser-Busch, which wants 800 of the companys non-polluting behemoths.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is, but then you look at their sales projections. They're estimating sales will go from $150 million in 2021 to $3.2 billion by 2024, but the article's wording makes it sound like a "plummet" due to production cuts. It's confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, but then you look at their sales projections. They're estimating sales will go from one hundred fifty million dollars in twenty twenty one to three point two billion dollars by twenty twenty four, but the article's wording makes it sound like a plummet due to production cuts. It's confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far, Nikola hasnt generated much revenue but estimates sales will jump from $150 million in 2021 to $3.2 billion by 2024 as it ramps up productions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a bit contradictory. And, uh, for heavy-duty trucks, especially short-haul, there's actually a decline in interest in gasoline. Which is, you know, a bit of a problem for their gas models.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a bit contradictory. And, uh, for heavy-duty trucks, especially short-haul, there's actually a decline in interest in gasoline. Which is, you know, a bit of a problem for their gas models.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the company has yet to deliver trucks to commercial customers, theres been a steady uptick in interest in hydrogen for heavy-duty trucks, particularly long-haul vehicles, as fuel cell power systems are much lighter than batteries and can be refueled about as fast as diesel and gasoline models.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. But they've got some big partners, though, right? Like Iveco, Bosch, even Hanwha, the solar panel maker.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. But they've got some big partners, though, right? Like Iveco, Bosch, even Hanwha, the solar panel maker.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Along with Iveco, Nikola also counts Bosch, Meritor, South Korean solar panel maker Hanwha and Norways Nel as key industrial partners helping get it sci-fi-styled semis on the road and fueled up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: True, true. So, it's just this incredibly complex picture of hype, ambition, and, uh, a whole lot of financial hurdles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, true. So, it's just this incredibly complex picture of hype, ambition, and, uh, a whole lot of financial hurdles.
